message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurrent bacterial infections and undetectable serum levels of immunoglobulins suggest an X-linked recessive disorder affecting B-cell development and is most likely to be Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Common variable immunodeficiency is a primary immunodeficiency typically affecting adults with normal B-cell differentiation. DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a developmental defect in the thymus and parathyroid glands, and does not typically present with decreased immunoglobulin levels. Hereditary angioedema is caused by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor and does not typically present with recurrent bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of recurrent bacterial infections and undetectable immunoglobulin levels suggest Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Common variable immunodeficiency may cause reduced levels of immunoglobulins, but not all isotypes would be undetectable. DiGeorge syndrome involves T-cell deficiencies, and hereditary angioedema is a disorder of the complement system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recurrent bacterial infections and low levels of immunoglobulins and B cells suggest Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects B cell development and leads to the absence of immunoglobulins. The other options typically present with different symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a primary immunodeficiency disorder. The undetectable serum levels of all isotypes of immunoglobulins and reduced levels of B cells are characteristic of Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is an X-linked disorder that affects males. Common variable immunodeficiency is also a possibility, but it typically presents in adolescence or adulthood. DiGeorge syndrome presents with cardiac abnormalities and thymic hypoplasia. Hereditary angioedema is a rare genetic disorder that causes episodes of swelling in various parts of the body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, which is consistent with Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Common variable immunodeficiency would show decreased levels of all immunoglobulin classes, not just undetectable levels. DiGeorge syndrome and hereditary angioedema have different presentations and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has undetectable serum levels of all isotypes of immunoglobulins and reduced levels of B cells, which suggests Bruton agammaglobulinemia, a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by absent or decreased B cell development and a lack of immunoglobulin in the bloodstream. Common variable immunodeficiency and DiGeorge syndrome typically present with normal or elevated levels of immunoglobulins, while Hereditary angioedema is characterized by recurrent episodes of angioedema, not recurrent bacterial infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of recurrent bacterial infections, undetectable serum levels of immunoglobulins and reduced levels of B cells suggest Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder that causes a defect in B-cell development. Common variable immunodeficiency also causes reduced levels of immunoglobulins and B cells, but it usually presents after adolescence. DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by thymic hypoplasia and T-cell deficiency. Hereditary angioedema is caused by a deficiency in C1 esterase inhibitor and presents with recurrent episodes of swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with undetectable serum levels of all isotypes of immunoglobulins and reduced levels of B cells, which is typical of Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Common variable immunodeficiency would show decreased levels of all immunoglobulins, but not undetectable levels. DiGeorge syndrome would present with thymic hypoplasia and T-cell deficiency. Hereditary angioedema would show episodes of swelling and difficulty breathing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has recurrent bacterial infections, which suggests an immune deficiency. The undetectable serum levels of all isotypes of immunoglobulins and reduced levels of B cells indicate Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Common variable immunodeficiency would have normal or decreased immunoglobulin levels, and DiGeorge syndrome would present with T cell, not B cell, deficiency. Hereditary angioedema is not an immune deficiency disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of recurrent bacterial infections, undetectable serum levels of immunoglobulins, and reduced B cell levels are characteristic of Bruton agammaglobulinemia, a primary immunodeficiency disorder affecting B cell development. Common variable immunodeficiency is also a primary immunodeficiency disorder but is characterized by low levels of multiple immunoglobulin isotypes. DiGeorge syndrome affects thymus gland development and is characterized by T cell deficiency. Hereditary angioedema is not related to immunodeficiency but is a disorder of the complement system.
